name: Give Back: Volunteer Projects in Your Community

text.text: Give Back: Volunteer Projects in Your Community

Despite what social media says, life’s not all about merch, models and selfies. Throughout London there are a heap of amazing projects to get involved with, offering you a chance to give back to that community of yours. So if you’re looking for a self-improvement project that is more rewarding than a jog round the block, take a look at these volunteering opportunities - you may learn something amazing.
Become a literacy pirate

Hackney Pirates run year-long literacy interventions for primary school kids in the ends. Pupils that need help with their reading and writing skills get referred by teachers to become pirates. Classes are taught in all sorts of exciting ways (lots of role-play and games) and they're held in what the kids like to call an 'underground base'.

Sign up to become a crew mate (one-to-one tutor) and they'll train you up in-house - so no worries if you've forgotten all about alliteration and assonance.
Click for Hackney Pirates
Host cocktail parties in care homes

Arts charity Magic Me supports elderly communities in all sorts of lovely ways. Aiming to bridge the gap between generations, it gets young people involved in a number of projects with the elderly. These range from theatre productions to, our personal favourite, cocktails in care homes. 

Once signed up you can pop along to one party a month (these happen all over London), serve drinks and have a proper natter with the residents.
Click for Magic Me...
Swap skills with refugees

Time Piece is a skills sharing app tackling social integration issues faced by refuges, by connecting them with local Londoners.

You could swap English for Arabic lessons or Syrian cooking classes; share music or sewing skills; or simply get together for a gig or game of footy. You can browse users in your area based on interests, so if someone’s missing some canine company, why not bring them along on your next dog walk?

(The app is still in development but you can register on their website and get started right away.)
Click for Time Piece...
Bond with a youngun'

The Kids Network connects young professionals to vulnerable children in Camden and Hackney. London can be a lonely place, but this program means the likes of us can feel more connected with our community, rather than just being the face of gentrification. 

You get paired up with a little pal between the ages of 8-11, helping support their confidence and just hanging out. Luckily you get plenty of training and a support network to help you casually inspire a young 'un. No pressure.
Click for The Kids Network
Teach English to refugees

If you've still not used that TEFL you got in a post-uni meltdown, put it to good use with a charity like CARAS (Community Action for Refugees and Asylum Seekers). They do a stellar job supporting people of all ages from refugee and asylum-seeking backgrounds who live in South West London. 

They are often looking for qualified volunteer English teachers to teach adults and children. If that's not you, try their youth clubs, day trips out, women's drop-in centres and advocacy support.
Click for CARAS...
Reduce food waste and feed some folk

Food waste plain sucks, especially when so many Londoners are hungry. Join the good fight by volunteering with Food Cycle. It works by taking surplus food from supermarkets, setting up in spare kitchen spaces across London and making tasty, nutritious meals. These go to people at risk of food poverty and social isolation. 

According to the charity, UK supermarkets throw away 400,000 tonnes of food every year, so there's plenty to go around.
Click for Food Cycle...
Make a friend, end social isolation

Cities are notoriously solitary places, with loneliness sited as a main catalyst for mental health issues and even premature death among older people and disabled adults. 

Dorcas Befriending Project in North London are working to eliminate social isolation by thoughtfully pairing volunteers with someone in their community that needs the company. Commit to just one hour a week and spend your time together gardening, baking, playing cards, going out to the pub, or just having a chat and a cuppa. You can also try telephone befriending if you live a bit further away.
Click for Dorcas...
Join an all female collective

Remember Brownies and Girl Guides? Well they're still a thing. But with over 70,000 girls on their waiting list, Girl Guiding are crying out for volunteer guides. Register with what skills you can offer and how much time you have to spare, and they will find the perfect role for you. These range from running regular group activities and being a guide leader to doing one-off sessions sharing your particular skills.
Click for Girl Guiding...
Help homeless people rebuild their lives

St Mungo's is leading the way for homeless charities, helping people find solutions to their housing, employment, training and health needs. They've got all sorts of volunteer opportunities so you can find one that fits your skills. Give being a breakfast club volunteer a go, or try running art groups, delivering massages, running gardening workshops, and offering translation services to the homeless refugee community. You can also apply to be part off the first response team getting people of the street as quickly as possible.

Some of their volunteer spots only require 1.5 hours a week - pretty manageable if you ask us.
Click for St. Mungo's...
Little extras

Alert. Use the app Streetlink to alert homeless services to people sleeping rough near you. This is especially important during the cold winter months which put many lives in danger.

Donate. You can donate dry food, unused toiletries, warm clothes and new bedding to homeless charities or your local food banks. Just check their guidelines to make you're getting the right thing.

Reach out. Contact a charity you are interested in to find out if your specific skills could be helpful. Social media, photography, finance, admin... there's plenty of jobs to be done behind the scenes.
